snippet: A lucrative, little-known tax maneuver has produced a startling pipeline of art moving across the United States as collectors cleverly — and legally — exploit the tax codes.
abstract: Lucrative, little-known legal tax maneuver that allows American art collectors to purchase art works tax-free from other states if they loan them to museums in tax-friendly states has produced pipeline of art moving across the country; practice, which allows buyers to sidestep sales taxes and use taxes, has generated debate about public access to art and the cost to taxpayers.

byline.original: By GRAHAM BOWLEY and PATRICIA COHEN
byline.contributor: Robin Pogrebin and Carol Vogel contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: A lucrative, little-known tax maneuver has produced a startling pipeline of art moving across the United States as collectors cleverly — and legally — exploit the tax codes.

headline.main: Buyers Find Tax Break on Art: Let It Hang Awhile in Oregon
